history.content:
I would say take 70 over fall and 170/61C over spring. My reasons are as follows. Others can append counterarguments or corroborations below.

1. I wouldn't worry too much about which professor would give better grades. I think you'll find that the distribution is pretty close. Just do your best. You can always use great services like CSM to help boost your understanding of the material to prepare for exams if you are concerned about that.

2. I would not recommend taking 70 and 170 at the same time. There will certainly be others who disagree with this, but I firmly insist that if you do not have a solid background in mathematical and logical reasoning, 170 can be needlessly difficult. Given that you are concerned about difficulties in CS 70, it seems to me that you do not have the solid background and maturity needed for 170 (without taking 70 first). Of course, I intend no umbradge in saying this.3. More of an aside, getting into 170 as an undeclared student is not typically too hard, but it depends on the semester, and there are no guarantees whatsoever. I would not rely on your ability to get into 170 if you do not Phase I it.

children.subject:
1. It sounds pretty miserable to take CS 70 with Sahai and CS 170 at the same time. You're going to have two miserable problem sets every week, regardless of whether Sahai's exams are slightly easier than Walrand's.

2. Technically, there isn't much interdependence in terms of material. CS 170 relies on proof techniques like proof by contradiction or induction, but that's only like 1-3 lectures worth of CS 70.

3. You can usually get into 170 phase 2 if it's not a popular professor like Papadimitriou (which is fortunately the case for spring).

4. The only condition where I can see you maybe making that work out is if you have a really amazing study group of peers in CS 70 and CS 170, so you can help each other get unstuck on problems. If you don't really know people in both classes, things are probably going to be really rough.

Another thought on Walrand's 70 style. I took it last semester with Rao and Walrand. For Rao, I went to his every single lecture and enjoyed it. However, for Walrand, I just couldn't understand much of the material, 1 because of his slightly misleading Belgium accent, 2 because of his material was generally harder than Rao's I guess. That being said, I am definitely not saying anything negative about Prof Walrand as it's just that he wasn't my type of professor. If you don't have problems with accent, just go for Walrand. He is good. As far as Sahai is concerned, his problem sets are definitely way too long and time-consuming. I've seen his style in 16A/B and have heard of it from my friends taking 70 with him in the past. Try avoid 70 with Sahai and 170 at the same time, both because of the workload and also because of the maturity required in these two.
Alternatively, take 70/61C in the fall and 170/something else in the spring.

history.content:
Hi. I've heard that CS70 with Walrand in the fall is hard, and that I will both learn more and get a better grade in CS70 by taking it with Sahai in spring. I'm fine with harder problem sets; it is the tests that I am worried about. With this said, I originally planned to take CS70 in the fall, and CS61C and CS170 in the spring.

I was wondering whether I should instead take CS61C over fall with Boser and CS70 with Walrand along CS170 during spring. I plan on absolutely being able to take 170 over spring because I plan to take 188 over summer, and if I can't, then I will be 2 UD behind my plan. I've been told that taking CS61C over fall as opposed to CS70 and therefore not declaring would mean that I would pretty much not get into CS170 for spring. How true is this rumor? Would I be able to enroll in CS70 and CS170 at the same time, or does CS170 fill up far too fast for people who have not declared.

tl;dr 70 over fall and 170/61c over spring or 61c over fall and 170/70 over spring?

Thanks.
history.subject: CS70 vs CS61C Fall 2016. Help.
